metadata.title: Synthesis of SnS/TiO2 nano-tube arrays photoelectrode and its high photoelectrocatalytic performance for elimination of 2,4,6-trichlorophenol

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Separation and Purification Technology
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/seppur
Synthesis of SnS/TiO2 nano-tube arrays photoelectrode and its high photoelectrocatalytic performance for elimination of 2,4,6-trichlorophenol
Xinyi Zhanga, Yingjie Gaoa, Li-chao Nengzib, Bo Lia, Jianfeng Goua,⁎, Xiuwen Chenga,b,⁎
a Key Laboratory of Western China's Environmental Systems (Ministry of Education), Key Laboratory for Environmental Pollution Prediction and Control, Gansu Province, College of Earth and Environmental Sciences, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, PR China bAcademy of Economics and Environmental Sciences, Xichang University, PR China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: SnS/TiO2 nano-tube arrays Photoelectrode Photoelectrocatalysis Visible light 2,4,6-Trichlorophenol
A B S T R A C T
In this study, SnS decorated TiO2 nano-tube array (SnS/TiO2 NTAs) photoelectrode, which was applied for degradation of 2,4,6-trichlorophenol under simulated visible light illumination, was synthesized by anodization combined with electrodeposition strategy. Afterwards, series of the systematical physicochemical properties were measured. Results show that SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode exhibited improved visible light range of 650 nm and transient photocurrent density of 0.119mA cm−2, as well as higher photo-generated charge separation efficiency, because of the synergistic effect between TiO2 and SnS. Also, the enhanced charge separation and photoelectrocatalysis (PEC) mechanism were further confirmed by photoluminescence spectroscopy and visible light assisted PEC efficiency for degradation of 2,4,6-trichlorophenol. It is worth mentioning that SnS/ TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode displayed excellent stability and reusability, for the degradation efficiency of repeated experiments were all over 90% after 5 runs. All these results indicated SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode has great potential for the degradation of organic pollutants in waste water treatment.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Along with the damagement of emerging organic pollutants in environment growing serious under the background of rapid economic development, exploiting high-efficient environmental functional materials is imminent [1]. For developing an environmentally friendly and low cost strategy for emerging organic pollutants decontamination, photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) technology shows great potentiality in the application of environmental remediation [2]. Thus, photoelectrocatalytic materials have been the hotspots in the field of new environmental functional materials for a decade. In the process of wastewater and waste gas treatment, the application of photocatalysis is also very extensive [3]. Among them, TiO2 is one of the most studied semiconductors, which is not only stable, non-toxic, but also has high photocatalytic efficiency [4]. We know that the mechanism of photocatalysis is actually: the semiconductor material absorbs enough energy from ultraviolet and visible light. When it is equal to its band gap energy, it generates photogenerated electron hole pairs and redox reaction with pollutants to achieve the purpose of degradation [5].
However, TiO2 still has some disadvantages, which greatly limits its photocatalytic performance. Since the band gap of TiO2 is about
3.20 eV, the photoexcitation process is highly dependent on ultraviolet irradiation. Ultraviolet rays are only 4–5% in the solar spectrum, while visible light accounts for 40% [6]. In addition, the high recombination rate of photogenerated electrons and holes during photocatalytic reaction is also one of the reasons for reducing the photocatalytic activity of TiO2 [7]. Therefore, for extending its response to visible light, many modification methods have been developed such as metal deposition, ion doping, semiconductor coupling, and sensitization and so on [8].
As we all know, creating heterostructures between two or more semiconductor materials, can improve the efficiency of photogenerated charge separation, so that the PC performance gets promoting [9]. At present, studies have found that TiO2 NTA can be combined with some narrow band gap semiconductors to form heterostructures and enhance its visible light PEC activity. Generally, Cu [10], ZnO [5], SnO2 [11], Ag and AgCl [12,13] are considered. The SnS selected in this study has a large light absorption coefficient (> 104 cm−1) and a direct band gap energy of 1.2–1.5 eV [14], which is an ideal narrow-bandgap semiconductor. However, there have been few studies on the performance of SnS to enhance the PC and PEC properties of TiO2 NTA.
Chlorophenols (CPs), as a series of typical organic pollutants in the water, are widely used in the chemical, forestry, and woodworking
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.seppur.2019.115742 Received 5 May 2019; Received in revised form 16 June 2019; Accepted 26 June 2019
⁎ Corresponding authors at: Key Laboratory for Environmental Pollution Prediction and Control, Gansu Province, College of Earth and Environmental Sciences, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, PR China (X. Cheng).
E-mail addresses: goujf@lzu.edu.cn (J. Gou), chengxw@lzu.edu.cn (X. Cheng).
Separation and Purification Technology 228 (2019) 115742
Available online 27 June 2019 1383-5866/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
industries, and most CPs are toxic, mutagenic, and carcinogenic [15]. As for the targeted pollutant in this study, 2,4,6-trichlorophenol is used as a dye intermediate, fungicide, preservative, etc. in daily life. It can cause serious environmental problems, including the death of animals and plants. Especially, it is extremely toxic to aquatic organisms and can cause adverse effects on the water environment. In addition, its irreversible damage to the body is worthy of attention. To solve this kind of refractory pollutants, different strengths of ultrasonic waves, ultraviolet radiation and catalysts are commonly used [16].
Therefore, in this study, a highly ordered and well aligned TiO2 nanotube array was first prepared by anodization. SnS was then modified on the surface of the original TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode by electrodeposition techniques. Subsequently, in order to study the physicochemical properties of the SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode, the samples were subjected to scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), UV–visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV–Vis DRS) and photoelectrochemical (PECH) measurements. In addition, the PC/PEC efficiency of the SnS/ TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode was also evaluated by the active hydroxyl (·OH) radical generated by fluorescence detection during the degradation of the TCP solution. As hypothesized, the photoelectrode of TiO2 NTAs modified with SnS exhibits stronger visible light absorption, higher charge separation efficiency, and better degradation of TCP. Finally, the mechanism of visible light PEC improvement is also discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and reagents
sections.text: In this study, all chemicals used were of analytical grade and were used without any purification. Ti foils (purity > 99.5%, 90mm×10mm×0.5mm) were purchased from Shenzhen Forte Metal Materials Co. Ltd. All the reagents including propanol, anhydrous ethanol, hydrofluoric acid, nitric acid, ammonium fluoride (NH4F), glycerine, methanol, Na2S2O3, SnCl2 and 2,4,6-trichlorophenol (TCP) were kindly provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Noted, deionized water was always used throughout this experiment.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode
sections.text:
According to the previous studies [17–21], highly ordered TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode could be obtained by anodization of Ti foils in the presence of NH4F electrolyte. The specific process of anodizing Ti foils to prepare TiO2 nanotube array (TiO2 NTA) photoelectrodes is: ultrasonically degreased the fresh Ti foil by using propanol, anhydrous ethanol, and deionized water for 10min in the traditional anode (Ti foil)-cathode (Pt plate) system, before the anodization. After drying at room temperature, the mixture was immersed in a mixed solution of hydrofluoric acid, diluted nitric acid and deionized water at a volume ratio of 1:4:5 for 30 s and then washed it for several times with deionized water. Then, the treated Ti foil was dried at 343 K before placed it in a mixed solution containing NH4F of 0.5 wt% and glycerol of 60% (v/ v). Clean Ti foil was used as anode and Pt plate as cathode, in a conventional two-electrode reaction chamber, with the temperature of 313 K, the constant potential of 20 V and reacted for 2 h. Finally, the resulting anodized sample was rinsed with absolute ethanol and deionized water and placed in an oven at 378 K for 4 h.
Next, the pH of the solution was adjusted to 1.5–4.0 by adding H2SO4 in a mixed solution containing 2–20mmol/L of SnCl2, 10–100mmol/L of Na2S2O3. The original titanium dioxide electrode and the platinum electrode were ultrasonically cleaned, then placed in the above solution starting an electrodeposition bath, and rinsed with anhydrous ethanol and deionized water before each deposition. The bath temperature was kept at room temperature. The deposition current density was controlled between 1 and 5mA/cm2 with a deposition time
of about 1.5 h [22].

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization of SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes
sections.text: Quanta 200F field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) was used at a voltage of 20 kV to record the apparent morphologies of the SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode. In addition, in conjunction with SEM, an EDS was used for the measurement of the elemental composition of the sample, the mass percentage of each element, and the number of atoms. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the sample was obtained by a D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu kα radiation ([λ]= 0.15418 nm) with accelerating potential and the applied current keeping at 40 kV and 30mA, respectively. Next, the X ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is measured on the PHI-5700ESCA device with the Al Kα X ray source to explore the surface elements of the sample. UV–Visible Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy (UV–vis DRS) measurements of samples were performed by using the Shimadzu UV-2550 spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere, and white BaSO4 powder was used as the reflectance reference. Finally, photoluminescence (PL) spectrometry was performed on a fluorescence spectrophotometer (FP-6500, Hitachi, Japan). The slit width is 3 nm.

sections.heading: 2.4. PEC decomposition of 2,4,6-trichlorophenol
sections.text: In order to evaluate the PC, EC and PEC performance of SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes, the representative organic contaminant 2,4,6- trichlorophenol was used as the target pollutant in the experiment. In a homemade quartz photoreactor, 50mL of Na2SO4 electrolyte (0.1 mol L−1) and TCP (5mg L−1) were added, and the SnS/TiO2 NTA photoelectrode was vertically fixed in the reactor. Because the balance of adsorption/desorption needed to be established, magnetically stirred the reactant in the dark for 30min at first. A 35W xenon lamp was then provided with luminous intensity of 67mW cm−2, and the sample was collected at intervals of the same period of time. Each time, the sample was filtered through a 0.22 μm membrane and immediately measured by the Shimadzu LC 10A High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) equipped with a Kromasil KR100-5C18 column (20mm×4.6mm i.d.). The mobile phase was a mixture of 20% deionized water and 80% methanol, the flow rate was 0.8mL/min, the detection wavelength was fixed at 294 nm, and the injection volume was 10 μL. In the comparison experiment, the PC activity of the pure TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode was tested under the same conditions but with no external potential and supporting electrolyte. Meanwhile the entire PEC process must be measured under the procedure above. In addition, the external potential +1.0 V is applied and controlled by a dual-channel output DC power supply (Agilent U8002A).

sections.heading: 2.5. Photoeletrochemical (PECH) measurement
sections.text:
The PQSTA 128 N electrochemical workstation, with the traditional standard three-cell structure of SnS/TiO2 NTAs electrodes, platinum foil and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) which were used as photoanode, counter electrode and reference electrode respectively, was used to study the PECH characteristics of the SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode. With the frequency range of 0.01 Hz to 1MHz, and the supporting electrolyte of 0.1mol L−1 Na2SO4 solution, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) curves of the sample in dark and with xenon lamp irradiation are recorded respectively, under the open circuit voltage (OCP).
2.6. Hydroxyl radicals (%OH) measurements
Referring to the previous research experience [23,24], by using fluorescent probe method, the Hitachi FP-6500 fluorescence spectrophotometer detected 2-Hydroxy-terephthalic acid (TAOH), which was produced by the terephthalic acid (TA) and %OH radicals generated on
the surface of SnS/TiO2 NTAs after illumination at 425 nm. In the experiments, the detailed experimental procedure was the same as the measurement of PEC activity except that 0.5mM TA was used in place of the TCP aqueous solution.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
SEM images of pristine TiO2 NTAs and SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes are presented in Fig. 1. The typical top view images (Fig. 1a) demonstrate that pristine TiO2 NTAs prepared by anodization have clear highly ordered nanotube structure with an average diameter of 120 nm and wall thickness of 20 nm. As shown in Fig. 1b, after electrodeposition with SnS, TiO2 NTAs still remained its integrated morphology. In addition, some spherical nano-particles (marked with arrows) with an average diameter of 30 nm were irregularly covered onto the surface of TiO2 NTAs. According to the EDS images of TiO2 NTAs and SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes shown in Fig. 1c and d, mass percentage and atomic number percentage of elements, Ti,O in TiO2 NTAs and Ti,O,Sn,S in SnS/TiO2 NTAs, could be seen clearly. Therefore, we have reason to preliminarily conclude that spherical nanoparticles are SnS.
For acquiring information of the sample prepared in the crystal structure, the typical XRD patterns of pristine TiO2 NTAs and SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes was collected and shown in Fig. 2 [25]. Noted, the dominant diffraction peaks can be well indexed to the anatase phase (JCPDS No. 21-1272), rutile phase (JCPDS No. 87-920) and the Ti metal
phase (JCPDS No. 44-1294) both exhibited by TiO2 NTAs [26], which were marked distinctly with A, R and T in the XRD patterns, respectively. Compared with the pristine TiO2 NTAs, SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode performed two additional and strong diffraction peaks located at 30.7°, 31.74°, correspond to (1 0 1), (1 1 1) planes of orthorhombic SnS phase (JCPDS NO. 39-0354) with the Pbnm (62) space group [25,27], respectively, demonstrating that SnS was indeed deposited
onto the surface of TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode. In order to further confirm the introduction of SnS, the XPS technique was used to further clarify the surface chemical states of SnS species in as-prepared samples (SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode), The high-resolution Sn 3d and S 2p orbit scans of SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode was measured. As illustrated in Fig. 3a, a set of spin-orbit doublet at about binding energy values of 486.88 eV and 495.35 eV could be clearly observed, which could be ascribed to Sn 3d5/2 and Sn 3d3/2, respectively [28], and the gap between Sn 3d5/2 and Sn 3d3/2 level is 8.4 eV, which indicates a bivalent oxidation state of Sn [26]. Furthermore, as shown in XPS spectrum (Fig. 3b) of S 2p, there are two peaks can be found. After fitting, peaking, the peaks at 161.1 eV and 162.4 eV should be assigned to S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2 (Fig. 3c), respectively, which is indicative of sulfur as divalent S2− in SnS [29,30]. Thus, we can reasonable conclude that cubic SnS species were indeed covered onto the surface of TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode, which could greatly increase the transfer and separation efficiency of charge carriers, as well as the visible light activity.
In order to deeply prove the advantage of SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode in terms of visible light response, UV–vis DRS was measured for analysising the optical property of SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode. Meanwhile, pristine TiO2 NTAs was contrastive referenced. Clearly, as seen in the Fig. 4, both two samples displayed the typical visible light response performance in the UV region of the spectra and the DRS response threshold is at about 390 nm [31], which is mainly attributed to the energy band structure of TiO2. The specific reason is that when the optical absorption at the wavelength range lower than 390 nm, the
electron transitions from the valence band to conduction band (band–band transitions, O 2p→ Ti 3d) [32]. Besides, in visible region, because of the trapped charge carriers and some color centers of pristine TiO2 NTAs, as well as the absorption of incident light by the nanotubes, TiO2 NTAs could performed broad light absorbance [17]. Moreover, compared with pristine TiO2 NTAs, SnS/TiO2 NTAs presented a significant red shift and covered absorption range in both UV and visible light band from 400 to 800 nm, which could be attributed to the introduction of deposited SnS species. To a certain degree, it has enhanced the visible light response capacity of SnS/TiO2 NTAs.
In addition, the conclusion in the previous study [33] was that SnS possessed direct energy gap of the layers changed from 1.30 to 1.41 eV. Using the Tauc plot method (Fig. 4b) [50,51], the estimated bandgap energy of SnS was 1.30 eV. Therefore, we have reason to draw conclusion that SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode should possess higher visible light PC performance than pristine TiO2 NTAs.
The efficiency of energy conversion from light and electric to chemical mainly depends on the separation and transfer of photogenerated charge carriers [42]. In the view of this, for evaluating the photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) performance of SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode, here we used a series of electrochemical testing to analysis the situation about separation and recombination of carriers in SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode. Specifically, photoelectrochemical (PECH) properties of sample were recorded and shown in Fig. 5. Obviously, as exhibited in Fig. 5a, it can be discovered that with several on–off cycles of 35W intermittent Xenon light illumination, both TiO2 NTAs and SnS/ TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes created photocurrent, achieving well reproducibility and stability. Notable, on account of the low diffusion of charge carriers, spikes clearly appeared both in pristine TiO2 NTAs and SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes, when the Xenon light was abruptly on or off. The photocurrent density of SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode reached the maximum around 0.119mA /cm2 at each time Xenon light illumination, which was about 1.78 times larger than that of pristine TiO2 NTAs sample (0.067mA/ cm2), revealing that the combination of SnS and TiO2 improves the charge separation efficiency and visible light response efficiency. What’s more, these results also explained that SnS nano-particles were indeed deposited onto the surface of TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode, which was also in accordance with the XRD, XPS and DRS results.
To better discover the PEC properties of SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), as a mature and reliable technique, was used to further state the photoelectrocatalytic activity of the sample, embodied by electron transport resistance. As we all know, the resistance of electron transfer and separation efficiency of photoinduced electron–hole pairs at the contact
interface between the electrode and electrolyte solution could be got from the semicircle diameter in the Nyquist plots of EIS indirectly [34]. The smaller the semicircle diameter in the Nyquist plots is, the smaller electron transport resistance is, the higher photoelectrocatalytic efficiency sample has. Thereout, at open circuit voltage (OCV), from the EIS response of pristine TiO2 NTAs and SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes in Fig. 5b, we cloud draw a conclusion that under the condition of Xenon illumination, the photoinduced electron–hole pairs in both the TiO2 NTAs and SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode could be more
effectively separated and transferred than in the dark. Furthermore, not only in the dark, especially with the Xenon illumination, the diameters of curve in Fig. 5b representing SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes were smaller than those representing TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes, revealing that the photoinduced electron–hole pairs in SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode could be separated and transferred effectively, because of the Schottky junctions existed between SnS species and TiO2 NTAs. These results suggested that SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode should own higher photocatalyst performance at the same time, which was also well agreed with the XPS, DRS and the above transient photocurrent results.
Widely known, electron generation and accumulation at the surface of photocatalysts under visible light illumination decided the OCP of them [43]. Simply to say, when both charge accumulation and recombination reached the competitive equilibrium, the OCPs of both TiO2 NTAs and SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes reduced rapidly to the most negative value and then remained a stable state [20]. When the light is on, the open circuit potential of the photoelectrode will decrease to a lowest value in a steady state. On the contrary, when the light is off, the OCP ascended more rapidly, the higher the electron separation and migration capability of the photoelectrode [45]. As exhibited in Fig. 5c, with a 350W Xenon lamp irradiation, the potential of SnS/TiO2 NTAs and pure TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode decreased sharply and stabilized to the lowest value, −0.361 V cm−2 and −0.257 V cm−2, respectively. More importantly, for the SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes, the OCP picked up more rapidly than that of TiO2 NTAs as the light was switched off, which proved that SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes performed higher abilities of electronic separation and migration. From the following, we can see the photocatalytic activity will be improved, which was also well agreement with the above results.
2,4,6,-Trichlorophenol, a dye intermediate, fungicide and preservative, was testified to be dangerous to both human beings and aquatic organism although it was at trace level in water [35]. For assessing the PEC performance of SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode by comparing with pristine TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode, 2,4,6,-trichlorophenol aqueous solution was choice as the target organic pollutant used in degradation experiment. According to Fig. 6a, it could be apparently shown that the rate of degradation under both the direct photolysis without photoelectrode and the adsorption in dark were so low that could be even neglected. As expected, the EC、PC and PEC efficiencies of both TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode and SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode became better and better in turn, from the rising trend of the removal rate. It is worth mentioning, the EC, visible light PC and PEC performances of pristine TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode were greatly improved by decorated with cubic SnS species, achieving maximum degradation rate at 99.9% with 120min illumination in the presence of +1.0 V(vs. SCE). The advanced photocatalytic activity of SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode was primarily attributed to the formation of narrower band gap SnS result in the enhancement of visible light absorbance and charge separation efficiency.
By analyzing the mechanism of previous photocatalytic degradation [19,20,23,24,36–39], %OH radicals playing a leading part in the degradation of refractory contaminants. Therefore, in order to deeply study the interal mechanism about PEC performance of SnS/TiO2 NTAs, by comparing fluorescence intensities of 2-hydroxyterephthalia acid (TAOH) derived from the reaction between TA and %OH radicals, the result had been detected and shown in Fig. 6b. It should be noted that with 120min Xenon illumination, SnS/TiO2 NTAs displayed much greater TAOH intensity than that of pristine TiO2 NTAs, so the conclusion could be come to that there should be a larger generation amount of ·OH radicals possessing from the degradation process of SnS/ TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode, owing to the greater visible light response and higher photogenerated carriers separation efficiency, signifing that SnS/TiO2 NTAs was supposed to own stronger visible light PC activity than that of others (Testified by Fig. 6a). However, if there’s no Xenon irradiation, distinct fluorescent peak won’t be existent at 425 nm by SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode.
Based on the above studies, the mechanism of enhanced visible light PEC degradation of 2,4,6-trichlorophenol by SnS/TiO2 NTA photoreflector was proposed, as shown in Fig. 7. Generally, the O2 affinity level (O2/O2−) is about 0 eV (−0.046 eV vs. SHE) [40], while the valence band (VB) and conduction band (CB) of the TiO2 semiconductor are 2.86 eV and −0.34 eV [17], respectively, and the band gap energy is
3.20 eV. At the zero charge point, the CB and VB potentials of SnS can be calculated by the following equation:
= + −E X E 0.5EgCB 0 (1)
= +E E EgVB CB (2)
where X is the absolute electronegative of the semiconductor, which is defined as the geometric mean of the absolute electronegativity of the constituent atoms. For SnS, X is 5.26 V, and E0 is the energy of free electrons on the hydrogen scale (−4.5 eV) [44], and Eg is the band gap energy (1.30 eV) [22]. ECB and EVB of SnS are estimated to be 0.11 eV and 1.41 eV, respectively. Under visible light, the electrons of TiO2 and SnS are excited from the valence band to the conduction band, leaving holes in the valence band. On the other hand, due to the recombination of the two materials, the electrons on the TiO2 conduction band migrate to the conduction band of SnS, meanwhile, the residual holes on the valence band of TiO2 are also transferred to the valence band of SnS, thereby further enhancing the separation rate of electron and holes. Further, when a current is applied externally, a large amount of electrons flow toward the cathode, which also achieves the above object. Photogenerated h+ on VB can oxidize H2O to produce %OH radicals or directly oxidize 2,4,6,-trichlorophenol (contribute less) [47]. On the other hand, the absorbed O2 molecules are reduced to %O2− radicals by the e− on the CB [48], which can further react with water to produce %OH radicals. Finally, the active material such as %OH formed by oxidation of the separated electrons and holes with oxygen-containing substances and water molecules is effective in degrading the organic pollutant 2,4,6-trichlorophenol. It is obviously found that %OH radicals play as the main active species in the PEC degradation process [49].
In order to further determine the charge separation efficiency, the photoluminescence (PL) spectra of the original TiO2 NTAs and SnS/ TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode were measured in the range of 350–600 nm at room temperature. The PL spectra of the two semiconductors were studied to know the electronic structures, optical and photochemical properties, and the surface processes of electron and hole conduct, in addition, the ability to capture, migrate, and recombine of photogenerated carriers [41]. It is well known that the PL signal is due to light induced e/h+ recombination, the longer lifetime of the photogenerated charges corresponds to the slower recombination process and shorter lifetime of the photogenerated charges to the faster migration process. Therefore, as can be seen from Fig. 8, the SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode exhibited the lower band edge recombination with an emission peak at 469.7 nm than original TiO2 NTAs, and the peak of SnS/TiO2 NTAs tended to be smooth but the peak of TiO2 NTAs was sharp. It was finally concluded that SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes
possess stronger photocatalytic positive in the present of its higher charge separation capability which inhibits the recombination of charges, lengthening the survival time of the charges.
It is known that evaluating the quality of a catalyst, stability and reusability are two of the most important factors. Thus, in order to prove that the prepared SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes own practical application potential, several consecutive PEC experiments were carried out. As can be seen in Fig. 9, the PEC efficiency of the degradation of 2,4,6-trichlorophenol on the SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode remains a stable high value after undergoing five successive degradation cycles. From this, we can reasonably conclude that SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode will have practical prospects in wastewater treatment.
In previous studies, we also used other narrow-bandgap semiconductor materials for the modification of TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes, for example, MnO2/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode, Cu2O/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode, Ag3PO4/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode, CuS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode and so on. By comparing with the above four composite photoelectrodes, SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode has the following advantages: (i) better recyclability and greater degradation efficiency than MnO2/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode [18]; (ii) lower cost and less required applied voltage than Cu2O/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode [17]; (iii) better stability and environmental adaptability than Ag3PO4/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode [46]; (iii) narrower band gap energy and superior e−/ h+ separation efficiency [31].Thus, the SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode
has a wide application prospect.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes modified with narrow bandgap semiconductors SnS were successfully synthesized by anodization and electrodeposition. Subsequently, the physicochemical properties of prepared photoelectrodes were characterized by SEM, XRD, XPS, DRS and photoelectrochemistry (PECH), severally. In addition, the photocatalytic (PC) ability of the SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode is reflected through the rate of degrading 2,4,6-trichlorophenol and the activity of hydroxyl radicals generated during a period. The results show that the composite photoelectrode SnS/TiO2 NTAs performs better for the light response in whole visible light range. Specifically, under 120min xenon illumination and with +1.0 V (vs. SCE) supplement, the material SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode exhibits a higher transient photocurrent density (0.119mA/cm2) and charge separation efficiency, as well as higher PEC activity for 2,4,6- Trichlorophenol degradation rate (99.9%). Therefore, it is shown that the SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode has strong visible light absorption capability, narrow band gap energy and high charge separation efficiency. This study provides new strategies and insights for the preparation of efficient photoelectrodes and their application in wastewater treatment.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: This work was kindly supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China (51508254), Nature Science Foundation of Gansu Province of China (1506RJZA216), Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (lzujbky-2015-137), Opening Project of State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure (SKL201509SIC), Open fund by Jiangsu Engineering Technology Research Center of Environmental Cleaning Materials (KFK1502), A Project Funded by the Priority Academic Program Development of Jiangsu Higher Education Institutions (PAPD) and Key Laboratory of Comprehensive and Highly Efficient Utilization of Salt Lake Resources, Qinghai Institute of Salt Lakes, Chinese Academy of Sciences.

referenceMentions.context: Along with the damagement of emerging organic pollutants in environment growing serious under the background of rapid economic development, exploiting high-efficient environmental functional materials is imminent [1].

For developing an environmentally friendly and low cost strategy for emerging organic pollutants decontamination, photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) technology shows great potentiality in the application of environmental remediation [2].
In the process of wastewater and waste gas treatment, the application of photocatalysis is also very extensive [3].
Among them, TiO2 is one of the most studied semiconductors, which is not only stable, non-toxic, but also has high photocatalytic efficiency [4].
When it is equal to its band gap energy, it generates photogenerated electron hole pairs and redox reaction with pollutants to achieve the purpose of degradation [5].
Ultraviolet rays are only 4–5% in the solar spectrum, while visible light accounts for 40% [6].
In addition, the high recombination rate of photogenerated electrons and holes during photocatalytic reaction is also one of the reasons for reducing the photocatalytic activity of TiO2 [7].
Therefore, for extending its response to visible light, many modification methods have been developed such as metal deposition, ion doping, semiconductor coupling, and sensitization and so on [8].
As we all know, creating heterostructures between two or more semiconductor materials, can improve the efficiency of photogenerated charge separation, so that the PC performance gets promoting [9].
Generally, Cu [10], ZnO [5], SnO2 [11], Ag and AgCl [12,13] are considered.
Generally, Cu [10], ZnO [5], SnO2 [11], Ag and AgCl [12,13] are considered.
Generally, Cu [10], ZnO [5], SnO2 [11], Ag and AgCl [12,13] are considered.

To solve this kind of refractory pollutants, different strengths of ultrasonic waves, ultraviolet radiation and catalysts are commonly used [16].

Widely known, electron generation and accumulation at the surface of photocatalysts under visible light illumination decided the OCP of them [43].

Simply to say, when both charge accumulation and recombination reached the competitive equilibrium, the OCPs of both TiO2 NTAs and SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrodes reduced rapidly to the most negative value and then remained a stable state [20].
On the contrary, when the light is off, the OCP ascended more rapidly, the higher the electron separation and migration capability of the photoelectrode [45].

metadata.abstractText: In this study, SnS decorated TiO2 nano-tube array (SnS/TiO2 NTAs) photoelectrode, which was applied for degradation of 2,4,6-trichlorophenol under simulated visible light illumination, was synthesized by anodization combined with electrodeposition strategy. Afterwards, series of the systematical physicochemical properties were measured. Results show that SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode exhibited improved visible light range of 650 nm and transient photocurrent density of 0.119mA cm, as well as higher photo-generated charge separation efficiency, because of the synergistic effect between TiO2 and SnS. Also, the enhanced charge separation and photoelectrocatalysis (PEC) mechanism were further confirmed by photoluminescence spectroscopy and visible light assisted PEC efficiency for degradation of 2,4,6-trichlorophenol. It is worth mentioning that SnS/ TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode displayed excellent stability and reusability, for the degradation efficiency of repeated experiments were all over 90% after 5 runs. All these results indicated SnS/TiO2 NTAs photoelectrode has great potential for the degradation of organic pollutants in waste water treatment.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
